assumedPriorKnowledge: Fluent conversion between percentages, decimals, and fractions
Calculating percentage of a quantity using multipliers
designPrinciples: Emphasis on nuanced applications over definitions

curriculumAlignment.outcomeDescription: Solve problems involving percentages including increases, decreases and financial applications using mathematical modelling

keyConcepts.name: Decimal multiplier method for percentage change
keyConcepts.description: Using multipliers efficiently: increase by r% = ×(1+r/100), decrease by r% = ×(1-r/100). Recognising when to multiply vs divide.
keyConcepts.advancedNote: Students should select method based on efficiency, not just familiarity

keyConcepts.name: Reverse percentage calculations
keyConcepts.description: Working backwards from final amount: if new = original × multiplier, then original = new ÷ multiplier. Applying to both increases and decreases.
keyConcepts.advancedNote: Focus on identifying WHICH percentage the final amount represents (not assuming it's the change)

keyConcepts.name: Successive percentage changes
keyConcepts.description: Understanding that consecutive changes compound: final = original × m₁ × m₂ × ... Order doesn't matter for multiplication, but intermediate values change.

keyConcepts.name: GST and tax calculations (bidirectional)
keyConcepts.description: Adding GST (×1.1) and removing GST (÷1.1). Finding GST component from inclusive price (÷11). Extending to other tax rates.
keyConcepts.advancedNote: Apply same logic to international VAT rates (e.g., UK 20% → ×1.2, ÷1.2)

keyConcepts.name: Profit, loss, mark-up, and margin distinctions
keyConcepts.description: Profit % = (profit/cost)×100. Margin % = (profit/selling)×100. Mark-up % = profit %. Converting between these measures.
keyConcepts.advancedNote: Given any two of {cost, selling price, profit %, margin %}, calculate the others

keyConcepts.name: Percentage change vs percentage point change
keyConcepts.description: Distinguishing 'increased by 5%' (multiplicative) from 'increased by 5 percentage points' (additive). Critical for interpreting statistics.
keyConcepts.advancedNote: Interest rate going from 4% to 5% is +1pp but +25% relative increase

keyConcepts.name: Simple interest with variable manipulation
keyConcepts.description: I = PRT applied flexibly: finding any variable given the others. Comparing interest scenarios. Annualising rates for comparison.
keyConcepts.advancedNote: Transition point to compound interest concept (preview Year 9)

keyConcepts.name: Multi-step financial modelling
keyConcepts.description: Combining discounts, taxes, fees, and percentage changes in realistic scenarios. Determining optimal financial decisions.
keyConcepts.advancedNote: Problems requiring students to set up their own calculation sequence

keyConcepts.name: Expressing relationships as percentage equations
keyConcepts.description: Translating 'A is p% more than B' into A = B(1 + p/100). Setting up equations to find unknowns in percentage relationships.
keyConcepts.advancedNote: Bridge to algebraic representation of percentage problems

keyConcepts.name: Percentage error and approximation
keyConcepts.description: Calculating percentage error = |actual - estimated|/actual × 100. Understanding acceptable error margins in different contexts.
keyConcepts.advancedNote: Connects to scientific measurement and data analysis

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Treating reverse percentages symmetrically (subtracting/adding the percentage from the new amount)
commonMisconceptions.correction: The final amount IS a percentage of the original. After 20% increase, final = 120% of original, so original = final ÷ 1.2, NOT final - 20%
commonMisconceptions.exampleError: Jacket costs $160 after 20% off. Student: $160 × 1.2 = $192 (wrong). Correct: $160 ÷ 0.8 = $200
commonMisconceptions.remediation: Ask 'What percentage OF THE ORIGINAL is $160?' Answer: 80%. So $160 = 0.8 × original
commonMisconceptions.targetedAt: Even strong students make this error when rushing or not visualising

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Believing successive opposite percentage changes return to original
commonMisconceptions.correction: Each percentage applies to the CURRENT amount. +10% then -10%: 1.1 × 0.9 = 0.99. The order doesn't matter but you never return to original.
commonMisconceptions.source: PMC - The problem with percentages (Chen & Rao, 2007)
commonMisconceptions.exampleError: Stock rises 25%, then falls 25%. Student says 'back to original'. Actual: 1.25 × 0.75 = 0.9375 (6.25% loss)
commonMisconceptions.remediation: Algebraic proof: (1+r)(1-r) = 1-r² < 1 for any r ≠ 0. Always a net loss!
commonMisconceptions.targetedAt: Sophisticated error requiring algebraic reasoning to fully understand

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Confusing percentage change with percentage point change in statistics
commonMisconceptions.correction: Percentage points are additive (4% to 5% = +1pp). Percentage change is relative (4% to 5% = 25% increase).
commonMisconceptions.source: Statistical literacy research; Media reporting analysis
commonMisconceptions.exampleError: 'Approval rating rose from 40% to 50%' - student says 10% increase instead of 25% relative increase (or 10pp)
commonMisconceptions.remediation: Practice with real statistical contexts; identify which interpretation makes sense
commonMisconceptions.targetedAt: Critical for interpreting news, surveys, and research findings

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Applying single equivalent discount to successive discounts
commonMisconceptions.correction: 30% off then 20% off ≠ 50% off. Multiply: 0.7 × 0.8 = 0.56, so equivalent to 44% off.
commonMisconceptions.source: Marketing mathematics research; Consumer behaviour studies
commonMisconceptions.remediation: Calculate 'what single multiplier achieves the same result?' then convert to percentage off
commonMisconceptions.targetedAt: Real-world application error with financial consequences

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Inconsistent base selection for percentage calculations
commonMisconceptions.correction: Always identify the base (denominator) first. Profit % uses cost as base. Margin % uses selling price. Change % uses original.
commonMisconceptions.exampleError: Cost $80, sold $100. Student calculates 20/100 = 20% profit instead of 20/80 = 25% profit
commonMisconceptions.remediation: Create decision tree: 'Percentage OF WHAT?' determines denominator
commonMisconceptions.targetedAt: Common in business contexts; critical for financial literacy

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Treating GST as simple addition/subtraction rather than multiplicative
commonMisconceptions.correction: GST is multiplicative: inc GST = ex GST × 1.1. To remove: ex GST = inc GST ÷ 1.1, NOT inc GST - 10%
commonMisconceptions.source: ATO Tax Super + You; Consumer mathematics research
commonMisconceptions.exampleError: $110 inc GST → student says GST = $11 (10% of 110). Correct: GST = $110 ÷ 11 = $10
commonMisconceptions.remediation: Think: 'If pre-GST was $100, GST adds $10 to make $110. So $110 ÷ 11 = GST amount'
commonMisconceptions.targetedAt: Practical error affecting real purchasing decisions

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Assuming percentage problems are always straightforward calculations
commonMisconceptions.correction: Many problems require setting up equations or identifying what's being asked before calculating.
commonMisconceptions.exampleError: 'After 15% discount and 10% GST, price is $93.50. Find original.' Student doesn't know where to start.
commonMisconceptions.remediation: Systematic approach: identify variables, write relationships, solve algebraically
commonMisconceptions.targetedAt: Higher-order thinking required; common struggle for procedurally-focused students

commonMisconceptions.misconception: Misinterpreting 'increased BY x%' vs 'increased TO x%'
commonMisconceptions.correction: 'Increased BY 25%' means new = 1.25 × old. 'Increased TO 125%' means new = 1.25 × old. 'Increased TO 25%' means new = 0.25 × old.
commonMisconceptions.exampleError: 'Sales increased to 150% of last year' interpreted as +150% (250%) instead of 150% (50% increase)
commonMisconceptions.remediation: Parse language carefully: 'to' indicates final value, 'by' indicates change amount
commonMisconceptions.targetedAt: Linguistic precision critical for word problem interpretation

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Stacked sales promotions: 'Extra 20% off already reduced prices'
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: A store advertises '40% off storewide, PLUS extra 25% off at checkout'. Is this better than 65% off?
realWorldPhenomena.context: $200 item: 40% off = $120, then 25% off = $90. Single 65% off = $70. Stacked = 55% total discount!
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: EOFY sales, Click Frenzy, Black Friday - JB Hi-Fi, Myer often stack discounts
realWorldPhenomena.cognitiveComplexity: Requires calculating equivalent single discount; comparing scenarios

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Uber surge pricing and reverse calculation
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Your Uber shows $45.50 with 1.3× surge. What would it cost without surge? Is the 30% extra actually 30% more?
realWorldPhenomena.context: With surge: $45.50. Without: $45.50 ÷ 1.3 = $35. Surge added $10.50, which is 30% of $35 (the base), not 30% of $45.50
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: Uber, DiDi, Ola - common transport for teens; NYE/event surge pricing
realWorldPhenomena.cognitiveComplexity: Reverse percentage with unfamiliar multiplier; distinguishing percentage bases

realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Bitcoin dropped 50% in June, then recovered 50% in July. Are you back to where you started?
realWorldPhenomena.context: $10,000 investment: -50% = $5,000. Then +50% = $7,500. Still down 25% despite 'equal' movements!
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: Crypto interest among teens; CoinSpot, Binance discussions; financial literacy
realWorldPhenomena.cognitiveComplexity: Successive changes with different bases; counter-intuitive result requiring proof

realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: A $550 laptop (inc GST) is 15% off. The receipt shows discount, GST, and final price separately. Can you verify each?
realWorldPhenomena.context: Original ex-GST: $500. Discount: $75 (15% of $500). New ex-GST: $425. GST: $42.50. Total: $467.50
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: JB Hi-Fi, Harvey Norman business pricing; understanding receipts
realWorldPhenomena.cognitiveComplexity: Multi-step with interleaved operations; verify intermediate calculations

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Casual loading vs hourly rate comparison
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Part-time gets $22/hr + 10% super. Casual gets $27.50/hr (inc 25% loading) but no super. Which earns more?
realWorldPhenomena.context: Part-time: $22 + $2.20 super = $24.20 total. Casual: $27.50 ÷ 1.25 = $22 base, so 25% more than base but no super.
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: First jobs at Woolies, Coles, Maccas; Award rates; superannuation
realWorldPhenomena.cognitiveComplexity: Comparing different percentage structures; interpreting loaded rates

realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Shapes went from 175g to 150g but price stayed at $4.50. What's the real percentage price increase per gram?
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: CHOICE investigations; Woolworths/Coles; household budgets; consumer awareness
realWorldPhenomena.cognitiveComplexity: Unit rate calculation combined with percentage change; requires setting up comparison

realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: ING offers 5.0% p.a. on first $100k. Up Bank offers 4.75% p.a. with no cap. At what balance does ING become worse?
realWorldPhenomena.context: At $100k: ING = $5000 interest, Up = $4750. Above $100k, extra $ earn 0% at ING. Break-even analysis required.
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: Teen savings accounts; Up, ING, Macquarie comparisons; intro to financial decision-making

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Sports statistics: efficiency ratings across different sample sizes
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Player A: 45% shooting on 200 attempts. Player B: 48% on 50 attempts. Who's actually better?
realWorldPhenomena.context: A: 90 makes. B: 24 makes. Percentage error consideration: smaller sample = less reliable. Expected range analysis.
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: NBL, AFL, NRL statistics; fantasy sports; data literacy
realWorldPhenomena.cognitiveComplexity: Percentage interpretation with statistical nuance; sample size effects

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Afterpay/buy now pay later fee structures
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: Afterpay charges merchants 4-6% per transaction. If a store adds 5% 'card fee', what's the real cost to you?
realWorldPhenomena.context: $100 item + 5% fee = $105. If you pay over 4 instalments with no interest, effective cost analysis vs upfront.
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: Afterpay, Zip, Klarna popular with young Australians; financial literacy
realWorldPhenomena.cognitiveComplexity: Fee structure analysis; comparing payment scenarios; hidden cost identification

realWorldPhenomena.phenomenon: Property price changes and stamp duty calculations
realWorldPhenomena.curiosityHook: A house was $800k in 2020, now $1M. If stamp duty is approximately 4% of purchase price, how much more duty is paid?
realWorldPhenomena.context: 2020: $32k duty. Now: $40k duty. Price increased 25%, but duty increased by $8k ($40k vs $32k) = 25% too. Why same %?
realWorldPhenomena.australianRelevance: Housing affordability discussions; NSW stamp duty; parental conversations about property
realWorldPhenomena.cognitiveComplexity: Linear percentage relationship; proportional reasoning; real adult financial context

scaffoldingSequence.name: Consolidation - Multiplier Fluency
scaffoldingSequence.focus: Rapid application of decimal multipliers; choosing efficient methods; mixed increase/decrease
activities: Speed drill: percentage change to multiplier (both directions)
Estimation challenges: 'Which is larger? 78% of 240 or 82% of 230?'

scaffoldingSequence.name: Core Application - Reverse and Tax Calculations
scaffoldingSequence.focus: Working backwards fluently; GST both directions; real-world pricing scenarios
activities: Reverse percentage with unfamiliar percentages (not just 10%, 20%)
Receipt interpretation: calculate and verify each component

scaffoldingSequence.name: Complex Scenarios - Successive and Combined
scaffoldingSequence.focus: Multiple percentage changes; stacked discounts; comparing scenarios
activities: Stacked discount vs single discount comparisons
Profit/margin conversions; percentage point vs percentage change
Error identification: 'Why is this calculation wrong?'

scaffoldingSequence.name: Financial Modelling - Multi-step Problems
scaffoldingSequence.focus: Complex real-world scenarios; setting up calculations; optimal decision-making
activities: Simple interest comparisons with different rates/times
Setting up percentage equations from word problems
Financial decision problems with justification required

scaffoldingSequence.name: Extension - Challenge and Transfer
scaffoldingSequence.focus: Novel contexts; algebraic reasoning; proof and generalisation
activities: Prove why +r% then -r% always results in net loss
Create your own multi-step percentage problem
Analyse misleading statistics using percentage point vs percentage

cognitiveLoadNotes: Assume foundational procedures are automated; focus cognitive load on problem analysis
Use completion problems (partial working shown) for complex scenarios initially
Interleave problem types early to prevent procedural fixation
Require estimation BEFORE calculation to develop number sense
Introduce algebraic representation alongside numerical to build connections
engagementStrategies: Use current, relevant financial contexts (Uber, Afterpay, crypto)
Error analysis with realistic student mistakes - 'find and explain the error'
Comparative scenarios requiring decision-making and justification
Counter-intuitive results that challenge assumptions (successive % changes)
Real receipt/bill analysis from Australian retailers
motivationFactors: Financial empowerment: detecting misleading sales and fee structures
Intellectual challenge: proving why intuitions fail
Real adult decisions: understanding job pay, savings, purchases
Critical thinking: analysing statistics in news and social media

interleaving.rationale: High-performing students benefit more from early interleaving (Rohrer & Taylor, 2007). Prevents over-reliance on surface cues.
interleaving.implementation: From Phase 2 onwards, every problem set mixes at least 3 problem types. Students must identify problem type before solving.

desirableDifficulties: Unfamiliar percentage values (17%, 23%, 8.5%) not just standard ones
Problems requiring identification of problem type before solving
Scenarios where common approaches fail (successive changes)
Insufficient information problems: identify what's missing

testingEffect.implementation: Weekly cumulative retrieval covering all prior phases
testingEffect.timing: Short diagnostic at start of each session; comprehensive review every 5th session
testingEffect.format: Mix of: rapid-fire procedural, word problem interpretation, error identification, explain-your-reasoning

transferExpectations: Apply percentage reasoning to novel contexts not explicitly taught
Recognise percentage problems embedded in larger scenarios
Self-correct by checking reasonableness of answers
Explain why common errors are incorrect

support: Provide worked example before similar problem
Allow calculator for arithmetic to focus on reasoning
Highlight key words in word problems
Offer bar model visualisation for reverse percentages
extension: Create and solve their own multi-step scenarios
Analyse real financial products (term deposits, loans)
Statistical significance and margin of error contexts

successCriteria: Fluently applies multiplier method in both directions
Correctly identifies base for percentage calculations
Distinguishes percentage change from percentage point change
Sets up and solves multi-step percentage problems independently
Verifies answers using estimation and inverse operations
advancedSuccessCriteria: Proves general results algebraically (e.g., why +r% then -r% < original)
Identifies optimal financial decisions with justification
Transfers percentage reasoning to novel unfamiliar contexts
Analyses and critiques percentage claims in media/advertising
